chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: The first topic is Independent Events and Dependent Events.

chunks.text: And the second topic is Dependent Events.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Suppose, I am doing a task.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: The name of the task is Rolling a Dice.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Usually, you will see 6 numbers in the dice.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: So, I will have a sample space of 1,2,3,4,5,6.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Whenever I roll a dice, if I want to find the probability of 1, then it will be 1 by 6.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Or if I want to find the probability of 2, then it will be 1 by 6.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Let us say that I rolled a dice for the first time.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: If I want to find the probability of 1, then it will be 1 by 6.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Similarly, if I want to find the probability of any number, then it will be 1 by 6.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: So, in this case, one event is not impacting the other event.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: That is what Independent Events mean.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: For example, if the probability of 1 is 1 by 6 in the first event,

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: in the first experiment or in the first throw.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: So, this event is not impacting this event.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Neither is this event impacting this event.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: So, this is what Independent Events mean.

chunks.title: Naive Bayes
chunks.text: Two events will never impact each other.
